UCGxTFvotP7PpXE6YqNQnw.text: Another interesting, hip place in Tiong Bahru, the kind that is frequented mostly by expats and local hipsters. It has the feel of an old canteen, reminding me of those desperately-trying-to-look-old, kitsch cantinas so popular in Mexico City, with tiled floors, posters on the walls and vintage marble tables, a bit crammed on the inside. To the untrusting observer, The Tiong Bahru Club may appear to be one of those places where form is more important than essence. However, the environment ultimately works and the place feels strangely authentic and inviting.The first interesting thing are the two different menus: East Asian and North Indian. Both of them contained snippets of information, kind of "explaining" the dishes. We were told to choose what kind of menu we wanted to have, so we chose the Indian menu (I'm always keen on Indian food). We had a very good, fragrant and spicy fish curry. Then I tried the masala chicken liver, which was spectacular. It was rich in flavour, while at the same time full of subtle surprises. I could say food tasted almost home-cooked, there was a special level of care involved. There's no way I couldn't love that.It must be hard to keep the balance of style and substance in a restaurant. My first impression of The Tiong Bahru Club was that of a place favouring the former. It is always good to be proven wrong. Here, style is no more than the background to a sense-appealing meal. I will surely come back.

qL0Ptde0hRLNyrVxCgyDwg.text: The overall look and feel of this venue is ok, that's why I still give 2 stars.The foods are overpriced compared to the quality offered. I took a cappuccino and a Cheese beef burger (22$ ++)The cappuccino is too milky, and when it was served, I don't feel like having ordered a real cappuccino (4 or 4.5 $ ++, see my photo). The minced beef in the hamburger was too salty.When I asked for ketchup, they give you ketchup in small package. I asked mustard twice, because the first time they did not say they don't have mustard, the second time they kind of simulate like they are looking for it then announce that they don't have mustard. Can't they say directly that they dont have if they already know...?About the bread, it seemed to me that they are using first price quality. The burger was not worth 22$

photos.caption: Photo of The Tiong Bahru Club - Singapore, Singapore. Forgot to talk about the bread that looks like a first price
Photo of The Tiong Bahru Club - Singapore, Singapore

wwitXgGqeUIlU4TErQZtuQ.text: A new upmarket restaurant has opened in Tiong Bahru! I know.. What's new right? Located at the corner of Eng Hoon St. And Seng Poh road, we've seen this place transform from an old coffee shop (our favourite Loo's Hainanese curry rice used to be here) transform into this upmarket eatery. At first glance, this place looked like just another upmarket, snooty diner, filled with expats, yuppies and a certain breed of Singaporean females that have a certain preference for guys I should not name. Anyway... What got us trying this place was the nostalgic feel and the fact that it did not serve the usual eggs Benedict, breakfast sets, waffles or pancakes, and they certainly didn't promote themselves as the next big coffee joint with magical beans from the bottom of the Amazon River. Instead, what this place specializes in is... Indian food and chai!! Surprise surprise! Well.. I guess it made sense considering that the Brits and the Indians / Sikhs have long had a history together. Anyway... I'm a sucker for indian food so this place, despite how hard I tried to say no, still got the better of me. They have 2 sets of menus here, an Asian menu, with fried rice and soto Ayam and an Indian menu. We decided to go for a Murgh Dum Briyani, my favourite Palek Paneer,a Masala Chicken Liver and what better way to wash down our food than with a nice pot of Himalayan Sikkih tea.First came the Briyani. A good sharing portion that could easily feed 2-3 pax. The rice was wonderfully fragrant with the spices and flavours beautifully infused in and the chicken, despite being the breast, was tender and oh-so-flavourful. So good in fact that it just might be one of the best Briyani's I've had in a while. Next was the Masala Chicken liver. Now this dish was the star of our lunch. It is literally to die for! The liver was nice and tender and the sauce, with all its onions and spices was amazing. Every bite was a dream and this dish is enough to bring us back for more. Finally the Paneer, my personal favourite. The sauce was nice and smooth without the spinach being over powering while the cheese was smooth and "bouncy". Only thing it could do with was a little more salt, otherwise it was another very good dish. The tea itself was nice and fragrant and proof that chaitime, the guys behind this restaurant, know their teas. Overall, it was s wonderful experience and the only reason this place didn't get a 5 is down to a few simple factors. A) indoor searing was a little tight, with most 4 pax tables nearly touching each other and effectively becoming a 3 top. B) service was slow as well, with the 2 waiters clearly being inexperienced and frankly a little lost most of the time. C) food did take a little longer than it should, with U.S. almost finishing our Briyani by the time the paneer came. D) the prices. A little on the strap side at around $20-$25 per pax for an Indian meal. Overall, I love how they kept some of the coffee shop's elements while updating it, leaving a nice nostalgic feel, down to the music choice. We'll definitely be back for more!

photos.caption: Photo of The Tiong Bahru Club - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of The Tiong Bahru Club - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of The Tiong Bahru Club - Singapore, Singapore

_i_qn9VEtEFCjEzQD0V7SQ.text: Understand why reviews continue to become lower. An attractive place that wants to portray itself as a "neighborhood" facility. In reality, however, the prices mirror the tourist spots on Orchard. S$12 for a small bottle of Tiger beer. Really? Seriously? It goes down hill from there. Won't return.

IYKXi2URYqWvLAlXl6mLbQ.text: Absolutely delicious Devil's Chicken Curry (at $16.80, a bit on the pricey side) really made my brunch! The sauce was bursting with flavor and spices, and the carrots, pork, and sausages were a fantastic accompaniment. A nice cup of chai went along with it superbly, and it was served with just the right amount of rice. I'm lactose intolerant, and it was lovely to find Indian in Singapore without ghee (clarified butter) so I could eat it! My friend's biryani was delicious too: light and fluffy, tasting of gardens.The outdoor seating was the perfect blend of the aircon from inside and the heat of the sidewalk, with people watching and a good breeze. Decor is cute and appealing - a blend of the club and the chaiwallah stand which both supply the place. The issue was that our server was quite obviously completely new and pretty inept (sorry, buddy, but you were.) He said they offered chai by the pot and let us order some - by the pot - but they only serve it by the glass, as the server who brought it over explained after our mystified glances at the solitary cup. He also said they were offering their Bento Box special but when I tried to order it, turned out that's only available on weekdays. Study your menus and learn your stuff, servers, so that your service can match with your fine establishment's prices.

photos.caption: Photo of The Tiong Bahru Club - Singapore, Singapore. Devil's Chicken, rice, and chai

XJY9LQZCVDMehdbFJAIR_w.text: On a hot Saturday afternoon, this place caught our attention because it was an old kopitiam refurbished to a modern day pub restaurant. We were just looking to quench our thirst. Seeing that Chaiholics was serving their tea specialties, we decided to give the chai a go. Firstly, I thought the teas were overpriced. $6.50 excluding taxes. But nonetheless we went for it. If the tea was good, no issues paying. But the tea was a big disappointment. Mainly that it tasted so watered down.  Additionally the spoons looked quite stained and dirty. We didn't dare use them. Such a shame.

photos.caption: Photo of The Tiong Bahru Club - Singapore, Singapore. Spoon needs thorough cleaning
Photo of The Tiong Bahru Club - Singapore, Singapore. Masala chai

EtM7_Py8Ce8YDWsH6ZYWnA.text: My review will be in line with most of the other ones. This place is average. Prices are expensive because of the locations but not because of the food taste which is average and overpriced. The manager and staff is nice but that's it. Another Tiong Bahru overpriced place that is most likely replacing a good ole Chinese joint.

photos.caption: Photo of The Tiong Bahru Club - Singapore, Singapore. Garlic Naan
Photo of The Tiong Bahru Club - Singapore, Singapore. Murgh Makhanwala (Spiced chicken in a buttery tomaty gravy)

jisRL8FwIbgOKd5e28kWog.text: Is it an eating place? A bar? Cafe? For a drinking place it's ok. I love the outdoor seating but the lights are too bright and the selection is quite limited. Didn't try the food.

photos.caption: Photo of The Tiong Bahru Club - Singapore, Singapore

TPLXi1g3EL5uEAVZbAHziQ.text: Kinda cool vibe indoor outdoor and not too hot. Not familiar with the vibe which I guess is like an old timey coffee shop or harkens back to colonial times. Am always uncomfortable with that bc yeah it might've seemed cool but was not cool for the majority of those not in the elite. Anyhow it was cool enough in the evening inside and they had mixed chairs and cool wood floor etc. just be careful if ur inside and then you moved your chair back and one leg falls off the elevated floor and u could fall and hit ur head. The food was actually pretty good - the Indian food only. We had chicken not the spicy one and it was juicy and citrusy and delicious. Also had the Dahl and the baigan bartha and naan and plain rice and one more thing. But it was all tasty and very spicy but good. The service was meh. I asked for ginger ale and they said no we don't have it. I pointed out on the menu where it was listed. Was advised they don't have it anymore. Asked what on this list they had. They have juice and coke. There were five more things listed. Ok I'll just have water. Have to flag them down if you want anything so they don't check back. But at least they don't bother you and let u stay to chat. They're not clearing ur plates as soon as ur done which was my experience in most other restaurants in Singapore.

Rie7N6xfl74vCCKOiZT2HQ.text: The food was excellent as was the service. Personally greeted and recommendations were made for strawberry lassi. It was very refreshing for a hot Saturday afternoon. We ordered the lamb biryani and murg tikka. That may be too much food for the two of us but it was so delicious, we finished it all. It is made to authentic north Indian standard, very difficult to come by here in Singapore. Loved the food very much! The ambience is great too. There are always people eating there regardless of what time of the day I go past it. Especially at night. It is however slightly pricey, at about $20-25 an entrée and $6-8 for a drink. Total of about $30-35 per person. I'll definitely be going back for more.

photos.caption: Photo of The Tiong Bahru Club - Singapore, Singapore. Brew of the week

kWr7VEGMwW49r6LckBU7JQ.text: If I could give it no stars I would. I went here on a friend's recommendation but either the management has changed or they were having a really bad night. The service was so bad it was comical. I don't see how any restaurant can charge prices like this when they offer such poor or no service. The menu prices were quite expensive.We struggled to get drinks. One waiter barely spoke English and when we did finally manage to order he would take an order  from 1 out of 7 people and disappear. We'd try to call the waiter back and he would take another order but forget half of the drinks. So we had to send our son to the bar to remind him. Then they ran out of beer. There was wine on the table but noone knew how much it cost.The food we had was OK but nothing to rave about. we only got a few entrees and this was only because my husband ordered them earlier as he had arrived 1/2 hour before  us. We had to get up and get our own plates as the waiters forgot.  After we had been in restaurant for 1.5 hrs we asked how our food was going and discovered the order had not been put through. The waiters were inept. We left as we'd run out of patience by then and everyone was grumpy.What was supposed to be a special birthday dinner was a disaster and I had 3 tired hungry children you feed at 9.30 pm.I've had better service in a hawker market for a fraction of the price!

lpAv6X-D2lxIpOdy3fUcrQ.text: 2 of us decided to walk there after coming back from the fantastic LeonardoDaVinci'sBlueprints exh on the final Saturday of 2014. It was pouring heavily but fortunately, the place was just 10mins' walk from apt. Was enticed by the 3for2pints of draft HoffbrauDunkel and had those with tandoori roll, sambal eggplant and lotsa complimentary groundnuts. Everything was tasty and ended up staying until they closed shop@10:30pm.

h8xghP4-B_GFW-RGdN5xaA.text: Distinctly average. Very disappointing considering the fact that everything else in this area, has really good food and service.
